Romy Zeiss; Carlos Antonio Guerra; Nico Eisenhauer

point occurrence; presence/absence
climatic; edaphic; habitat; topographic

Soil organisms are shown to be driven by climatic, topographic, habitat and edaphic factors. The main drivers of their distributions are (1) soil moisture, which is related to the availability of water through precipitation and can also be expressed as aridity (proportion of precipitation to evapotranspiration), (2) chemical and physical soil properties, such as pH, cation and heavy metal concentrations as well as soil texture, but also (3) the amount of organic carbon in soil that serves as resource for earthworms. In addition, (4) topographic factors were shown to drive large-scale distribution of many organisms including soil-related ones.

We included the following variables to represent climatic factors: Aridity Index, Mean annual precipitation (MAP), Mean annual temperature (MAT), and Snow cover (i.e., number of days with snow cover).  As habitat factors, we decided on the proportion of area covered by different land-use types, namely Agriculture, coniferous and deciduous Forest, Pastures, and Shrubland. In addition, we included Distance to urban areas, NDVI, and Population Density in our models. To account for topographic factors, we included Aspect (i.e., direction of a slope), Elevation, Slope, Distance to coast, and Distance to rivers. Finally, edaphic factors are depicted by Cation exchange capacity (CEC), soil texture expressed as Clay+Silt content, concentration of Copper (Cu), Mercury (Hg), Nitrogen (N), and Phosphorus (P),  as well as soil moisture, pH in H20, and content of Soil organic carbon (SOC).

Species-environment (pseudo-) equilibrium, No observation bias issues, Independence of species observations, Availability of all important predictors, Predictors are free of error, Niche stability/constancy & niche conservatism, No other extrapolation issues
biomod; maxent

For species with at least 100 records (i.e., present in at least 100 4 km² grid cells), we performed BIOMOD ensemble modeling using all 12 available algorithms to estimate weighted average probability of presence (TSS as evaluation criteria; Thuiller et al., 2003; 2009). The 12 available algorithms are ANN, CTA, FDA; GAM, GLM, MARS, MAXENT, MAXNET, SRE, RF, RFd, and XGBoost. For species with at least 10 records but less than 100 records, we performed Ensembles of Small Models (ESM; Breiner et al., 2015; 2018) using two complementary algorithms, namely GLM, and MaxEnt and estimated weighted average probability of presence (TSS as evaluation criteria).

Prior to model building, we standardized all predictor variables and used variance inflation (VIF) analysis to avoid highly correlated variables. We only considered variables with VIF<10. To avoid overfitting, we performed Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to reduce the number of predictor variables while maintaining the environmental heterogeneity. We included all axes that are needed to receive 80% of explained variance, that is the first 11 axes. Model fitting was done automatically as much as possible. In addition, we generated 1,000 individual background data for the models to increase their performances (i.e., randomly sampled pseudo-absences). Predictive model performance was assessed using TSS,  AUC(ROC), and Kappa.

species; genus; family

Occurrence data were collected in the frame of a regional monitoring project SoilRecon (PTDC/BIA-CBI/2340/2020) from 416 points sampled from October to December 2021 (Carvalho et al., 2025; Duarte et al., 2024). Soil biological properties were estimated in a uniform grid system of 20 x 20 km resolution. Topsoil samples were collected following established protocols (as described in Cano-Diaz et al., 2025). More details are described in the associated manuscript.
uniform, habitat types nested within uniform grid cells
Minimum sample size: present in 10 and 100 grid cells (1 km²), respectively.
We clipped all data to the political boundary of the NUTS II region Northern Portugal.

Spatial thinning: We defined presence/absence in each 1x1 km grid cell across Northern Portugal based on the respective occurrence records per taxon (i.e., species, genus, or family) using R (terra::rasterize()).
Data filtering: Taxa that had less than 10 occurrence records were excluded from the modeling. Sequencing data was grouped by taxonomy. More information can be found in Zeiss et al. (in Preparation).
No true absence data were used.

We generated 1,000 random background points within the study area per taxon using the R package biomod2. We followed advice from Barbet-Massin et al. 2012 to calculate model-specific background data that were shown to increase predictive performance.
Temporal bias: occurrences were recorded between October and December 2021, that may include seasonal climate variation.
For Species Distribution Modelling using BIOMOD, we randomly selected 80% of data for model calibration, leaving the remaining 20% for model evaluation in 10-fold cross-validation.
The models were evaluated using True Skill Statistic (TSS), area under curve (AUC) for ROC, and Kappa estimate.
We randomly selected 20% of our data for model evaluation (10-fold cross-validation), and did not validate the predictions with an independent dataset.

We selected 25 predictors based on our understanding of the ecology of the earthworms. Four climatic variables: aridity index, mean annual precipitation (MAP), mean annual temperature (MAT), and snow cover (i.e., number of days with snow cover). Eight habitat factors: five land-use types (agriculture, coniferous and deciduous forest, pastures, and shrubland), NDVI, distance to urban areas, and population density in our models. Five topographic variables: elevation, aspect (i.e., direction of a slope), slope, as well as distance to coast, and distance to rivers. And eight edaphic factors: cation exchange capacity (CEC), soil texture expressed as clay+silt content, concentration of copper (Cu), mercury (Hg), and phosphorus (P), as well as soil moisture, pH in H20, content of soil organic carbon (SOC).

Information on the data source for each environmental variable are given in the paper. We downloaded all data from the respective databases listed in Zeiss et al. (2024) and Zeiss et al. (in Preparation).

Time periods of data collection are ranging from 1 year (1 sampling campaign) to 11 years, and from hourly measures (e.g. CHELSA climate variables) to yearly measures (e.g. CORINE land cover data). For time series, the mean value of the yearly measurements was calculated using ArcGIS.
Environmental layers were downscaled to ~1 km² using the ArcGIS function Zonal Statistics, or the R function terra::project() as described in Zeiss et al. (2024).

Spatial bias: Data gaps in few layers for certain grid cells. Temporal issues: Environmental data do not reflect sampling conditions due to strong variation in sampling periods and missing detail information at and on sampling times.

Predictor variables were standardized and we used variance inflation (VIF) analysis to avoid highly correlated variables. We only included weakly correlated variables (VIF<10) in the final Species Distribution Models.
We selected variables according to the literature (see main text).
We removed variables with variable inflation factor VIF>10.

For species with at least 100 presence records, we used the R package "biomod2" to create an ensemble model with all ten available algorithms (GLM, GBM, GAM, CTA, ANN, SRE, FDA, MARS, RF, RFd, XGBOOST, MAXENT, and MAXNET). For species with at least 10 records but less than 100 records, we performed Ensembles of Small Models (ESM, R package "ecospat") using three complementary algorithms, namely GLM and MaxEnt.
